results.notes:
On decaying hemlock log.
Spores 13-17 × 5-7. A few scoped from a drop appeared to faintly show 3-4 septa. I revisited the site and made a subsequent collection (12/14) from the exact same patch of fruit bodies. Spore dropped were not septate (many examined using a better scope). Some contained a single medium-sized guttule and/or several tiny guttules.
6th photo shows what I believe to be conidia.
Last 4 photos represent a collection made from the exact same patch of fruit bodies 2 days after the original collection.

results.notes:
Spores 6.5-7.5 × 3.5-4.5.
Gills with a yellowish/greenish tinge toward the margin (not captured in photos). This may be due to pigment having seeped through the pileus of these post-mature fruit bodies.
Location very close to where obs 479719 was found; possibly the same log.
Pleuro/Chrysocystidia attenuated at the apices (somewhat different than the mucronate cystidia found on obs 479719). The cystidia seen in the photo here match the appearance of those seen representing H. fasciculare at Mushroom Expert.
The gestalt of the fruit bodies seen here better matches my concept of H. capnoides than H. fasciculare.

results.notes:
I am assuming this is a densely woolly, quite brown variant, going largely by the color of the gills. There were a good many of these on just one large hardwood log in a red oak, sugar maple, basswood forest.
The only two I measured, both shown photographed singly, were about 9 mm and 18 mm across, but I did not pay much attention to assessing the size range.
Spore print failed. Interestingly, the specimen shrank much more in drying than another acquisition of presumed same species that day.

results.notes: Collected a rotting log with immature example of this mushroom on 9/12/21 (see OBS 468705) and followed its development over time. Second observation on 9/18/21 (see OBS 469370), followed by this observation on 10/7/21. Beautiful orange-yellow caps and gills with typical foul smell for this species. This flush finally began to lose color and decay with the onset of cold weather near the end of October. Will keep the log over winter and expect these to re-emerge next season.

results.notes:
See also observation 480664. On a grass culm, likely Ammophila sp. Very small, 1 – 2 mm in diameter.

Found by Ava Arvest.

Microscopy by Jack Johnson, who says:

“I have used Rolf Singers monograph to Favolaschia, and landed in “Species incompletely known” and did not find any matches, although It is possible that more recent resources could bear better fruit.
Seems to be in the subsect. Depauperatae but again I’m aware this subsection may have more recently been divided/reassessed.
Spores, broadly elliptic to subglobose, most always with a single droplet and a strong apical plug
(7.4) 7.5 – 10.6 (12.4) × (5.2) 5.3 – 6.8 (6.9) µm
Gloeocystidia and gloeovessels present in KOH. Two types of cystidia observed."

See also discussion on https://www.facebook.com/...
results.location_name: Loomis Lake State Park, Pacific Co., Washington, USA

results.notes:
Growing in needle litter along the side of a road near Pinus strobus, Pinus sp., Thuja occidentalis, Picea sp., Abies balsamea and Acer sp. Caps viscid; 18.7 to 25.2 mm wide and 8.2 to 10.6 mm tall. Gills sinuate. Veil present. Annulus absent. Stems 32.7 to 66.1 mm long and 4.5 to 6.7 mm wide at the widest. Odor and taste not distinctive. 1M KOH negative on cap surface. Clamps present in the pileipellis and lamellar trama. Pleurocystidia scattered and similar to cheilocystidia. Cheilocystidia hyaline; some lightly encrusted or containing refactive content; utriform to fusiform. Cheilocystidia measurements: (25.3) 32.5 – 44.8 (46.4) × (8.7) 9.2 – 11.7 (12) µm; Q = (2.7) 3 – 4.3 (4.7); N = 30; Me = 38.4 × 10.5 µm; Qe = 3.7. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores brown and smooth. Spore measurements: (5.7) 6 – 6.9 (7.4) × (3.3) 3.4 – 4.1 (4.6) µm; Q = (1.4) 1.5 – 1.9 (2); N = 30; Me = 6.3 × 3.7 µm; Qe = 1.7

—

results.notes:
Fruiting bodies growing in soil/leaf litter adjacent to one another (as pictured) in a draw between two fairly steep sloping areas. Area of mixed oak (predominantly live oak) and pines (usually gray pine). Pale yellow/cream caps with white warts scattered on top, mostly toward perimeter. Appears to have white volva at base of stipe and white annulus near the top of a white, bulbous stipe. Closely packed white gills in cap.

Seems highly likely to be an Amanita; hoping an Amanita expert out there can help with exact ID…

results.notes:
Collar like Volva/Bulb(flared at margin).
NOTES:
Amanita section Amanita:
CAP: dull yellow tones with pinkish cast-especially toward center/disc.
Cap warts: pointed/symmetrical, many are pyramid shaped with grayish pink tones.
Not easily removed.

STEM: flaring collar like volva(at base).
Multiple concentric bands above bulb with peeling back scales(similar in appearance to Amanita cokeri).
Slightly cast pinkish where handled.
Veil: thick, slightly pink cast.
STEM CONTEXT: stuffed with cottony/gel center(similar in appearance to bisected collections of Amanita calyptroderma or Amanita vernicoccora I’ve examined).
NOT HOLLOW.
Bulb at base is definitely that of section Amanita=collar like, flared at top.
Odor: slightly sweet/bubble gum.
Fruiting singularly beneath Grand Fir.
I noticed it the prior week in button stage and waited for it to mature this week to photograph and harvest. Cap colors are distinct not faded or washed out and it is a rather young specimen.

Mailing dried specimen to RET on 12/16/21.

results.notes:
Fruiting in grass/moss beneath Grand fir and Western red cedar.
Fruiting bodies are not clustered, fruiting individually with distinct stem bases.
Translucent when young, dull creamy white when mature, drying with brownish tones(especially at fertile tips).
Some fruits are rounded/cylindrical.
Harvested specimens and spore printed directly on a glass slide for spore microscopy.
Spore Print: White.
Spores: subglobose/round. A few broadly ellipsoid.
Dehydrated 5 specimens and bagged for herbarium collection.
12/19/21: I returned to same location/harvested 7 more specimens and dehydrated for herbarium collection.

results.notes:
Growing scattered in soil among leaf litter near Populus deltoides, Quercus rubra, Fagus grandifolia and other small hardwoods. Caps densely scaly. Stems with scattered brown fibrils with white basal mycelium. Young stems with reddish-purple ground color. Pleurocystidia present as metuloids, similar to metuloid cheilocystidia. Pleurocystidia measurements: (55.8) 63.8 – 80.5 (84.6) × (13.8) 15.6 – 19.7 (20.4) µm; Q = (3.2) 3.3 – 4.9 (5.8); N = 20; Me = 72.6 × 17.6 µm; Qe = 4.2. Cheilocystidia present in 2 types: metuloids and smooth, rounded paracystidia, with both being hyaline. Metuloid cheilocystidia measurements: (34.7) 53 – 83 (102.8) × (16) 17 – 23.7 (24) µm; Q = (2) 2.5 – 4.1 (5.2); N = 20; Me = 66.4 × 20 µm; Qe = 3.3. Paracystidia measurements: (21.1) 22.4 – 33.2 (42.7) × (11.1) 13 – 17.4 (18.1) µm; Q = (1.2) 1.4 – 2.7 (3); N = 15; Me = 28.9 × 15.1 µm; Qe = 2. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores smooth and pale brown. Spore measurements: (8) 8.7 – 11.5 (14.1) × (4.9) 5.1 – 6.2 (7) µm; Q = (1.5) 1.6 – 1.9 (2.1); N = 30; Me = 9.8 × 5.6 µm; Qe = 1.7

Growing scattered in soil in the floodplain of Third Creek near Platanus occidentalis, Acer negundo, Acer sacchariferm, Ulmus sp., Salix nigra and Lonicera maacki. Caps fibrillose; 4.5 to 12.9 mm wide and 1.8 to 6.6 mm tall. Gills sinuate with 1 to tiers of lamellulae. Stems with white strigose basal mycelium; 1.7 to 18.3 mm long and 1.3 to 2.5 mm wide. Odor not distinctive. Taste slightly sour. Cheilocystidia abundant; fusiform and hyaline. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores angular. Spore measurements: (9.5) 11 – 13.4 (13.9) × (6.2) 7 – 8.8 (9.9) µm; Q = (1.3) 1.4 – 1.7 (1.8); N = 30; Me = 12.1 × 8 µm; Qe = 1.5

results.notes:
Beautiful phlegmaciums in mixed woods with indistinct scent. Mostly surrounded by madrone and ponderosa pines, but oaks and cedars also present.

Mostly dull yellow tones, but peculiar steely blue marginal ring around cap and wash at stem apex always. This color in the field reminded me of faded Entoloma medianox (“bloxamii), but in some parts of specimens, a bit paler and grayer. However, in age some of this blue color developed a violet tint.
Stipe context a pale tan, bulb dull ochraceous with white.

Spots of color on stipe below are KOH
KOH on the grayish purple/blue of the outer pileus is a cool lilac! (Photo to be added)

results.notes:
Growing abundantly among grasses in mud on a creek bank under Betula nigra. Caps dry. Stems dry and flexible, not scrobiculate and with white basal mycelium. Latex white and staining gills brown. Odor not distinctive. Taste radish-like. Spore print white. Pleurocystidia and cheilocystidia present as megacystidia. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores amyloid and partially reticulate. Spore measurements: (6.2) 6.8 – 7.9 (8) × (5.1) 5.3 – 6 (6.4) µm; Q = (1.1) 1.2 – 1.4 (1.5); N = 30; Me = 7.2 × 5.7 µm; Qe = 1.3

results.notes:
Under pines in the Ozark – St. Francis National Forest. Collected by Jay Pitts, microscopy by Alan Rockefeller.

ITS sequence doesn’t match any other sequences in Genbank – Closest match is MK909101, Cathathelasma subalpinum from China which matches 97.3%. Since Catathelasma ventricosum was described from Alabama, I think it’s very likely that this is C. ventricosum sensu stricto.

See also the recent paper on Catathelasma from China, https://mycokeys.pensoft.net/article/36633.

Jay’s iNaturalist observation: https://www.inaturalist.org/observations/102798039

results.notes:
These are relatively frequent here in the early and late winter. Saprotrophic, on needles and other debris on the foothills with grass and sagebrush, in open places.
Cap 1.5 3.8cm., flat at first, or convex with a central depression. Glabrous, light brown to reddish brown when moist, margin thin, straight or incurved, some with a faintly striated margin when moist, some lobed. Very hygrophanous, they become opaque, margin non-striated, pale tan when dried.
Gills whitish or slightly cream-pinkish, lighter than the cap and more concurrent with the stipe, short decurrent then moderately decurrent, close. Lamellae thin, fragile, relatively broad, with a series of lamellulae.
Stipe similar color than the cap, a little lighter; 2.5-3.5 cm x .2-.4 cm, glabrous, getting hollow with age, some compressed, appearing like a double stipe, base with whitish tomentum.
Context thin, brownish. Odor and taste non descriptive.
Spore deposit white; with guttules and looking spotted, some grouping as tetrads (6.4-7.5) x (3.2-3.8); ellipsoid-elongated, Q aver = 2.0; basidia (24-28) x (5.4-6.2); clamps present on the hymenophoral trama. Didn’t see any cystidia.

results.notes:
Geoglossum fallax collection notes:

Fruiting abundantly in moss/grass on the edge of Sleater Kinney Rd. Lacey, WA, USA.
Size range: 2.8cm-7cm tall.
Stem: coco brown, cylindrical, scaly(NOT HIRSUTE).
Cap: Grooved in center, dark brown(nearly black), flattened. Like lumpy kevlar in appearance.
Odor: not distinct.
Harvested 11 specimens for further analysis.
Spore printed 5 specimens on one slide and the remaining 6 specimens on a second slide(fertile caps laid flat on slides) for spore prints.
Also analyzed derma of cap/stem at 100x for presence of setae.
NO SETAE Present. Small lumps present/not setae.

Spores: Hyaline, all are aseptate(zero septa in over 20 spores analyzed). Common with this species.
Mounted 2nd slide with Lugol’s solution and all spores remain hyaline/inamyloid.
Dehydrated all 11 specimens and bagged for home herbarium collection/voucher.
results.location_name: Sleater Kinney Rd., Lacey, Thurston Co., Washington, USA

results.notes:
Cortinarius cinnamomeus GROUP notes:

Four specimens Fruiting in gravel/moss directly beneath Pacific Madrone(Arbutus menziesii). No other trees in vicinity.
Cap: 5cm wide, dark brown, dry.
Gills: bright orange in young and mature fruits.
Stem: 4cm long, slightly bulbous base.dark brown wen young to Dull rusty to yellow, degraded toward apex.
Context: hollow.
Odor: strongly of beets/radish.
Harvested 3 specimens for further analysis.
KOH Gills: cherry red.
KOH Cap: dark/wine red.
KOH stem: dark/wine red.
Spore printed a single cap directly on glass slide for spore microscopy.
Spore print: Rusty brown.
Spores: ellipsoid, roughened.
Dehydrated 3 specimens and bagged for home herbarium collection/voucher.
results.location_name: Swantown Marina, Olympia, Thurston Co., Washington, USA

results.notes:
Hypholoma dispersum notes:
Fruiting in conifer woodchips/mulch.
Scaly, snakeskin like stipe(covered in chevrons).

Gills: purple brown at maturity.
Harvested 4 specimens.

results.notes:
Growing on a hardwood leaf fragment near Quercus rubra, Fagus grandifolia, Carya sp., Acer saccharum, Carpinus caroliniana, Ostrya virginiana, Liquidambar styraciflua, Diospyros virginiana, Asimina triloba, Albizia julibrissin, Rhamnus sp., Fraxinus sp. and Ulmus sp. Caps white (2.5Y 9/2 in Munsell); not hygrophanous; 0.4 to 1.5 mm wide and 0.1 to 0.5 mm tall. Gills white (2.5Y 9/2), reduced and short-decurrent. Stems white (2.5Y 9/2) and finely hairy; 0.4 to 1.8 mm long and 0.1 to 0.2 mm wide. Basidiocarps air drying quickly. All structures inamyloid. Pileocystidia abundant: hyaline; smooth; some slightly thick-walled; setiform, flexuose or short and broadly clavate. Caulocystidia abundant: hyaline; thick-walled; smooth; cylindrical, setiform, awl-shaped or flexuose, rarely branched. Rhomboid crystals present on lamellar surfaces. Clamps present in the lamellar trama. Lamellar cystidia absent. Basidia 4-sterigmate and basally clamped. Spores inamyloid, hyaline, smooth and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (6.7) 7.5 – 10.8 (11.2) × (3.3) 3.8 – 5 (5.3) µm; Q = (1.7) 1.9 – 2.5 (2.8); N = 30; Me = 9.4 × 4.3 µm; Qe = 2.2

results.notes:
Growing scattered on the bark of a live Juniperus virginiana. Caps finely hairy and white; convex to pulvinate and shallowly umbilicate; 0.6 to 0.9 mm wide and 0.3 tall. Gills decurrent with 0 to 1 tiers of lamellulae. 10 full-length lamellae per cap. Stems white and finely hairy; 2.7 to 3.0 mm long and 0.1 mm wide. Basidiocarps drying quickly. All structures inamyloid. Pileocystidia hyaline, smooth and awl-shaped. Lamellar cystidia not clearly differentiated. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores inamyloid, hyaline, smooth and thin-walled, some with “tails” – possibly due to germatination. Spore measurements: (8.8) 9.1 – 12 (13.1) × (2.9) 3.5 – 4.4 (4.5) µm; Q = (2.2) 2.3 – 2.9 (3.5); N = 30; Me = 10.6 × 4 µm; Qe = 2.7

results.notes: This and several like it in a 15-foot radius pushed up through live oak and gray pine duff during a rainy period in late December. Have seen these here before, but it’s been several years. Cap is that sinister-looking faint yellow-green of A. phalloides. Specimen, which was growing just a few inches from a larger one, was 10 cm long, with cap about 5 cm wide and stipe about 1 cm wide. White annulus near top of stipe. White gills, white stipe. Stipe has bulbous base and volva evident when fruiting body is dug up.
